headline.main: AFFAIRS AT ALBANY.; Our Riotous Neighbors on Staten Island--Unsuccessful Effort to Cut the Throat of the Hell-Gate Pilot Bill--Two Brooklyn Bills Ready for the Governor to Sign--The Committees Called off from Worrying the Lobby--Governor Morgan Signs a General Tax--Extension Act, &c., &c.

docs.lead_paragraph: At 11 o'clock to-day there several bills were a special order and in file following arrangement: The bill providing for the punishment of certain offences--meaning the bill to prevent a gunpowder explosion under the new quarantine buildings of the adjustment of the legislature.

docs.snippet: A PAWNBROKER IN TROUBLE.--W. J. JACKSON, the well-knew pawnbroker, made complaint at the City Hall Police Court on Saturday against ARTHUR DONNELLY, carpet dealer, No. 98 Bowery, whom he charges with having defrauded him out of $20 under false...
docs.lead_paragraph: A PAWNBROKER IN TROUBLE.--W. J. JACKSON, the well-knew pawnbroker, made complaint at the City Hall Police Court on Saturday against ARTHUR DONNELLY, carpet dealer, No. 98 Bowery, whom he charges with having defrauded him out of $20 under false pretences.

docs.lead_paragraph: ITEMS.--JAMES McGINNISS was thrown from a wagon at the corner of Myrtle-avenue and Falton-street, Saturday, and severely, but not dangerously, injured. He was taken in charge by the First President Police.... MARY C. DIXON, a crazy woman from Kittingly, Conn., was found wandering in the streets by the Sixth Precinct Police Saturday night,

headline.main: AFFAIRS AT ALBANY.; A Substitute for the Registry Bill that finds favor--Assembly adopts the five minute rule--Ruthless slaughter of bad bills--The Increase of Wharfage--The Farce of the Corruption Investigations.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor of the New-York Times : The "fancy man" takes his recreation in the dog-pit of HARRY JENNINGS, of rat-killing notoriety; the admirers of the pugilistic art shine in all their glory at Hoym's Theatre ; the lovers of minstrelsy (!) find their summum bonum in the various basements where lager-bier and pipes abound ;

docs.snippet: The President, it appears, has got over the difficulty of selecting an suitable person to succeed Mr. FORSYTH as Minister to Mexico, and has determined to appoint the Hon. ROBERT McLANE. of Maryland, to that position. He is to be sent out untrammeled...
docs.lead_paragraph: The President, it appears, has got over the difficulty of selecting an suitable person to succeed Mr. FORSYTH as Minister to Mexico, and has determined to appoint the Hon. ROBERT McLANE. of Maryland, to that position. He is to be sent out untrammeled by instructions, and with full liberty to recognize whichever Government he may think proper, or neither, in his own discretion.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Reorganization of the ?? Party Proposed. A regular meeting of the People's Democratic General Committee was hold last evening at Mozart Hall, CHAS, A. MAY, Vice-President, in the Chair. There were 78 members present. The following plan for the reorganization of the Democratic party, and a constitution, were unanimously adopted:

headline.main: NEWS BY TELEGRAPH.; THE ACTORS IN THE SICKLES TRAGEDY. THE OCEAN MAIL BILL AGAIN REJECTED. OPINIONS RELATIVE TO THE PARAGUAY EXPEDITION. Dangerous Illness of Postmaster-General Brown. The Senate's Proposition for Increased Postage Tabled by the House. IMPORTANT FROM WASHINGTON. Action of Congress on the Appropriation Bills. Vote in the Senate to Authorize the Issue of Twenty Millions of Treasury Notes.

docs.lead_paragraph: Postmaster-Gen. BROWN is probably in a critical condition. He has been ill for several days of pneu- a monia, but this afternoon appeared much Improved. To-night, however, hemorrhage set in, from which It is feared he will die before morning. Such, I am assured, is the opinion of his medical advisers. The latest advices from him state that he Is somewhat easier, but his physicians give little hope of his surviving this illness.
